Thread: FDA Approes Generic 20mg AND 40MG

    • Show Printable Version

    • View Profile

    Registered Member
    Join Date
    Aug 2011
    Location
    USA
    Posts
    819

    FDA Approes Generic 20mg AND 40MG

    Just read that the FDA has approved a generic version of both Copaxone 20mg and Copaxone 40mg. I thought the generic for 20mg was approved a while ago. I switched to the 40mg prior to the 20mg approval.
    I'm a bit concerned. Is this good or bad for those of us using Copaxone? The insurance companies will insist we change.........
    Reply With Quote
  2. 10-31-2017, 01:56 PM #2
    its2much
    • View Profile
    • View Forum Posts
    Registered Member
    Join Date
    Aug 2011
    Location
    USA
    Posts
    819

    So I just requested a refill on my Copaxone 40 mg

    with my specialty pharmacy (CVS). I was asked if I wanted to change to the new generic Copaxone 40mg. Anyone else been asked that question?
    Reply With Quote
  3. 11-11-2017, 08:42 PM #3
    alanpgh
    • View Profile
    • View Forum Posts
    • Visit Homepage

    Join Date
    Apr 2003
    Location
    Pittsburgh, PA
    Posts
    186
    Here's the link to the Glatiramer Acetate website for more information:
    https://www.glatirameracetate.com

    This site provides some helpful information.

    Good Luck!
    Alan
    Reply With Quote
  4. 11-14-2017, 11:14 AM #4
    Mamabug
    • View Profile
    • View Forum Posts
    • Visit Homepage
    Moderation Team
    Join Date
    Aug 2003
    Location
    Kansas
    Posts
    4,206
    Thanks for the heads-up. I am a Copaxone 40 user. I hadn't heard about the generic version for Copaxone 40 so I did some research.

    https://www.nationalmssociety.org/Ab...axone%C2%AE-(G

    This NMSS article indicates that Mylan's generic form of Copaxone 20 is the second approved generic for glatiramer acetate 20mg' it was approved in October 2017. The first became available in 2015.

    They have also approved the first generic form of Copaxone 40.

    The article also says that there is no information, yet, about when this will become available or how much it will cost.

    My plan, likely, will be to wait until my next appointment with my MS Specialist, which is scheduled for February, and ask for her counsel and advice.
    ~ Faith
    MSWorld Volunteer -- Moderator since JUN2012
    (now a Mimibug)

    Symptoms began in JAN02
    - Dx with RRMS in OCT03, following 21 months of limbo, ruling out lots of other dx, and some "probable stroke" and "probable CNS" dx for awhile.
    - In 2008, I was back in limbo briefly, then re-dx w/ MS: JUL08    .
    - Betaseron NOV03-AUG08; Copaxone20 SEPT08-APR15; Copaxone40 APR15-present
    - Began receiving SSDI / LTD NOV08. Not employed. I volunteer in my church and community.
    Reply With Quote

post_text.surface_form: Just read that the FDA has approved a generic version of both Copaxone 20mg and Copaxone 40mg. I thought the generic for 20mg was approved a while ago. I switched to the 40mg prior to the 20mg approval. I'm a bit concerned. Is this good or bad for those of us using Copaxone? The insurance companies will insist we change.........
with my specialty pharmacy (CVS). I was asked if I wanted to change to the new generic Copaxone 40mg. Anyone else been asked that question?
Here's the link to the Glatiramer Acetate website for more information: https://www.glatirameracetate.com This site provides some helpful information. Good Luck! Alan

Thanks for the heads-up. I am a Copaxone 40 user. I hadn't heard about the generic version for Copaxone 40 so I did some research. https://www.nationalmssociety.org/Ab...axone%C2%AE-(G This NMSS article indicates that Mylan's generic form of Copaxone 20 is the second approved generic for glatiramer acetate 20mg' it was approved in October 2017. The first became available in 2015. They have also approved the first generic form of Copaxone 40. The article also says that there is no information, yet, about when this will become available or how much it will cost. My plan, likely, will be to wait until my next appointment with my MS Specialist, which is scheduled for February, and ask for her counsel and advice.
